principles.name: Accumulation Over Linear Path
principles.description: 'I don't see it as a path. I see it as an accumulation of experiences that has landed here, that represents more experience than most.' Career development is viewed as experiential accumulation rather than strategic progression.

principles.name: Corporate as Means, Consulting as End
principles.description: 'The corporate stuff isn't is helpful, but it was more of a means to the end, whereas the coaching CPA stuff is the vehicle to help.' Different types of work serve different purposes in the larger mission.

principles.name: Help as Core Motivation
principles.description: In consulting and CPA work, 'it was just all about helping people. That's all I really that because that's all I really wanted to do.' This represents the fundamental driving force behind career choices.

principles.name: Corporate for Knowledge and People Skills
principles.description: Corporate experience was valuable because 'it was more about knowledge and. And working with people' - serving as skill-building foundation for later helping-focused work.

principles.name: All Paths Through Owner Authority
principles.description: 'I don't understand. All paths go through the owner.' Fundamental operating principle that owner authority is the central organizing principle for all business change efforts.

principles.name: Reining In Over Redirecting
principles.description: 'I tend not to challenge much where they want to go unless they're trying to do too many different things. Then it's more about just reining it in.' Management of scope rather than direction changes.

principles.name: Employee Alignment Focus
principles.description: '95% of my one-on-one conversations with the individuals are to align them with where that owner wants to go.' Employee development serves owner vision rather than independent assessment of best practices.

principles.name: Trust Outcome, Question Diagnosis
principles.description: 'I don't always trust their diagnosis, but I'm comfortable with where the outcome is because it's where they want to go.' Separating destination acceptance from path validation.

principles.name: Better Operations Over Innovation
principles.description: 'Most of the time, it's more about just better operations, not necessarily anything new, but just better.' Focus on execution improvement rather than strategic innovation.

principles.name: Beneficial Dictatorship Leadership Model
principles.description: 'My collaboration probably works best when I'm managing the rules because I have a very deep sense of fairness in it, and people respond to that.' This involves setting rules and managing participation to ensure equity.

principles.name: Deep Fairness as Authority Foundation
principles.description: Leadership authority derives from 'a very deep sense of fairness' where 'everyone has an equal contribution this day, even though we have different places in the business.' This fairness is actively managed through 'who I call on and who I pull stuff from.'

principles.name: Neutral Facilitation Across Conflicts
principles.description: 'I'm not taking the side of sales or ops. I'm going to, we're going to be fair. We're going to be fair. You two have to work together' - maintaining neutrality while enforcing collaboration.

principles.name: Business as Profit-Making Entity
principles.description: 'It's an awareness that a business is a profit-making entity. Not to not exclusively, but it is in the business of making profit because otherwise, it doesn't survive.' Fundamental understanding that profit is necessary for business survival.

principles.name: Risk-Reward Owner Recognition
principles.description: 'A recognition that it's the owner who has taken on the risk, not the employee, and they are entitled to greater rewards because that is the way the system is set up.' Understanding the risk-reward structure of business ownership versus employment.

principles.name: Market Reward for Consistent Performance
principles.description: 'A recognition that if you do a good job for your customer or your client, you will get rewarded. But you have to do it consistently. The market rewards you for that work.' Understanding the customer-value-reward cycle.

principles.name: Non-Exploitative Hierarchy Understanding
principles.description: 'It doesn't mean that it's master-slave or anything like that' - acknowledging business hierarchy without accepting abusive power dynamics.

principles.name: Strategic Planning as Hurdle Identification
principles.description: 'The strategic planning session was not strategic planning. It was the identification of hurdles that are preventing us from moving forward. It was basically weaknesses.' Reframing strategic planning from visionary to problem-focused.

principles.name: Implementation Failure Despite Enthusiasm
principles.description: 'Most of those companies did not even take that day, even as they left feeling really pumped up. They still didn't do much with that information. They didn't fix what needed to be fixed.' Emotional engagement doesn't translate to sustained action.

principles.name: Tiny Steps with No Backward Movement
principles.description: 'Any change at a small business is tiny steps. You just what you've got to do is just make sure none of those steps are backward. Sometimes it happens, but a small step forward is huge.' The focus is preventing regression while making minimal progress.

principles.name: Shiny Object Syndrome as Implementation Killer
principles.description: 'The mistake all the business owners make is they still go after the shiny red object because of everything it promises. That big marketing plan or that new marketing plan never gets fully implemented... that's why.' Large initiatives fail due to poor execution management.

principles.name: Reality vs. Marketing Sexiness
principles.description: 'Anything can only be done in very small, incremental steps, the reason you don't read about that is from a marketing standpoint, that's not really very sexy, but it is reality. It is absolute reality.'

principles.name: Flow Through Environmental Preparation
principles.description: Flow states emerge when 'prior actions have basically minimized disruption, and everyone around me knows what they need to do.' The expert creates conditions where they can operate in a supporting role while maintaining decision authority.

principles.name: Anticipatory Leadership
principles.description: Effective leadership involves 'thinking ahead on what procurement needs were' and positioning team members (like hiring a sales assistant a year before) to step into roles when needed.

principles.name: Context-Dependent Empathy Development
principles.description: Empathy wasn't needed at The Limited because 'everyone in our department, we were all the same, and they were very much black and white, but a big company. There's not a lot of gray.' But at the family sawmill 'they're gray all over the place' requiring empathy to manage effectively.

principles.name: Holistic People Assessment
principles.description: At the sawmill, managing people requires understanding they're 'in rural Indiana. They're not very well educated. They work hard as hell, but some of these guys are learnedly farmers. They've already been up five hours. So you have to put all that together when you're thinking about people's performance.'

principles.name: People-Centered Problem Solving
principles.description: 'When you're working with any small business owner, one of the problems eventually becomes people. If your solution to everything is firearms or something like that, then you're not really helping them solve the problem.' Solutions must account for human complexity.

principles.name: People-Centered Identity
principles.description: When asked to articulate his holistic approach as a soft skill, Dan states simply 'I am people-centered.'

principles.name: Internalization Over Recall
principles.description: 'I just don't think I read. I don't even try to recall as much as if it was a good experience. Well, then I've somehow internalized it and it'll come out' - knowledge integration through internalization rather than conscious memorization.

principles.name: Photographic Memory Skepticism
principles.description: 'Everyone was just so impressed by it, and I thought, I don't know, I don't care. It's not a skill... To me, that's not useful knowledge' when referring to a partner with photographic memory who could recall exact document locations.

principles.name: Useful vs. Impressive Knowledge Distinction
principles.description: Distinguishes between impressive recall abilities ('where a piece of paper was in a file from three years ago') and actually useful knowledge for problem-solving and decision-making.

principles.name: Financial Verification as Trust Baseline
principles.description: 'What the owner is saying isn't backed up by the financial results that I'm seeing. So, there's a gap... at the beginning of any relationship, I don't accept very much of what they say until I can verify it on my own.' Independent verification as foundation for trust and understanding.

principles.name: Uncertainty Tolerance with Trauma Boundary
principles.description: 'I guess I'm okay with the uncertainty as long as it's not creating some major business trauma.' Comfortable operating in ambiguous situations unless they threaten business stability.

principles.name: Internalization and Conversation Weaving
principles.description: 'I think I just internalize that uncertainty and weave it into conversations with everyone, often the owner, just to get their take on things.' Using ongoing dialogue to gradually resolve uncertainty rather than forcing immediate clarity.

principles.name: Multi-Perspective Verification Process
principles.description: 'Whenever I get something verified, it's only after having had different conversations with different people.' Truth emerges through triangulation across multiple sources rather than single verification.

principles.name: Implementation Experience Over Theory
principles.description: 'Because I've tried to do it within an organization instead of just talking about it.' Differentiation comes from having actually executed profit improvement strategies rather than just advising on them.

principles.name: Context Understanding and Impact Assessment
principles.description: 'I think I can give context better than most, and I think I can understand the impact on the business better than most. That's still a function of experience.' Context and impact understanding as core differentiators.

principles.name: Interconnected Systems Thinking
principles.description: 'Nothing's in isolation. Raising prices is a lot more than raising prices. It impacts others in the organization as well as the customer.' Rejecting simple cause-and-effect thinking in favor of systems impact analysis.

principles.name: Implementation Complexity Recognition
principles.description: 'Giving them context in that here is what it could mean and here is how you can go about it so that they understand the pluses and minuses versus... Look, if you increase prices 10%, you're going to make X. Well, it's just not that easy.'

principles.name: Results Match Decisions - Harsh Accountability
principles.description: 'You are achieving exactly the results you deserve... The market doesn't care. If you're afraid to raise your prices, you're achieving the results that you want.' Direct accountability for business outcomes through decision consequences.

principles.name: Control-Based Responsibility
principles.description: 'Most of it is within your control. Even the customers are within your control.' Rejecting victim mentality by emphasizing areas of business control and influence.

principles.name: Value Message Over Activity Description
principles.description: 'Be as long as you're out there with a message of value and not what you do. You have a consistent message out there, you'll have customers.' Focus on value proposition rather than operational details.

principles.name: Decision Cascade Responsibility
principles.description: Poor results stem from decision chains: afraid to raise prices, unwilling to enforce supplier accountability leading to missed shipping dates and lost customers - all controllable decisions.

principles.name: Culture Gap as Core Uncertainty Anchor
principles.description: 'What is always in my mind and what is behind almost all the questions is the culture the owner describes is not the culture they have.' The gap between stated and actual culture serves as the primary diagnostic framework.

principles.name: Employee Perspective Analysis
principles.description: 'I'm trying to get a feel for the owner and how they communicate and put myself in the shoes of employees about how I'm hearing it.' Actively translating owner communication through employee perception filters.

principles.name: People Issues Disguised as Financial Issues
principles.description: 'The real issue is likely a people issue. It's not a financial issue. I just don't know what it is. They rarely are willing to offer that up early in the relationship. They'll describe it as a financial issue.' Understanding the pattern of misattributed problem sources.

principles.name: Free-Flowing Authentic Response
principles.description: 'I can't just keep trying to answer based on what I think my mental model is. I just have to answer it. If I go on a personal tangent, well, then I go on a personal tangent.' Authenticity requires abandoning preconceived self-narratives.

principles.name: Don't Try to Connect the Dots
principles.description: 'Don't try to connect the dots' - allowing natural responses rather than forcing coherent narratives during self-examination or conversation.

principles.name: Unconscious Reframing Mastery
principles.description: 'I think I reframe much more than I realize, but I don't think of it as reframing. When I think about collaborating, I try to encourage someone to do something different, and I end up reframing issues a lot until I find the one that resonates with them. I didn't realize I did that.'

principles.name: Family as Perspective Transformer
principles.description: 'Being a parent of three with now six grandchildren, it gives you a completely different perspective on things.' This family experience fundamentally alters how one approaches work and problems.

principles.name: Grandchildren as Mental Recharge Vehicle
principles.description: 'What the grandkids serve as in effect is they're like the recharge vehicle, mental. I can take on other people's problems all day long and help as much as I can and produce data or whatever they want. But then, at the end of the day, if you stop by and see some of the kids, you're forced to comment on how pretty the dresses that they're wearing today is an exact copy from some Disney movie.'

principles.name: Forced Attention Shift for Grounding
principles.description: 'By moving all of your attention over there, even if it's for a short period of time, probably healthy, maybe keeps you more grounded.' The complete attention shift from business problems to simple, present-moment interactions with children provides psychological balance.

principles.name: Human Connection as Consultant-Friend-Confidant
principles.description: The effectiveness comes from being 'both a consultant and a friend, to a degree, or a confidant' - combining professional expertise with personal relationship depth.

principles.name: Focus and Clarity Over Clarity and Confidence
principles.description: 'I talk a lot about focus and clarity more so than clarity and confidence.' The more established framework emphasizes cognitive clarity and attention management.

principles.name: Medical Model of Stress as Framework
principles.description: References a 'medical model of stress' that he uses in presentations but doesn't often think about outside of presentation contexts.

principles.name: Marketing Self-Awareness and Limitation
principles.description: 'Part of, you know, me and why I'm such a horrible marketer' - only thinking about core frameworks during presentations rather than leveraging them for consistent marketing.

principles.name: Firing as Favor to Overwhelmed Employees
principles.description: 'That person is simply not qualified, and I am doing them a favor because they're totally stressed out. The business, the owner is completely stressed out, and they're barely getting through the day.' Termination serves multiple stressed parties.

principles.name: New Guy Truth-Telling Role
principles.description: 'I'm the new guy, and all I'm doing is saying what no one else wanted to say.' External perspective enables difficult decisions that internal stakeholders avoid.

principles.name: Dual Fault Assignment
principles.description: 'I find fault with both the individual and the owner' - termination situations typically involve failures at multiple levels, not just employee performance.

principles.name: Dignified Exit Process
principles.description: 'First of all, it takes a long time because I document it and then have that difficult conversation with them and give them 30 to 60 days to think through based on my expectations. They will inevitably fail... we set a date in the future where we say, "I want you to start looking for a job while you still have all this work yet."'

principles.name: Fairness as Signal Management
principles.description: Challenge both sales and manufacturing equally to signal 'to everyone else right away that, well, sales is going to get their way today' would be wrong. When manufacturing claims low margins because 'we give it away,' respond firmly because 'we're all on the same team.'

principles.name: Business-First Governor Over Fairness
principles.description: 'The governor over sense of fairness is what do we have to do to make the business better? That's not necessarily what the owner says.' The ultimate arbiter is business improvement, not owner preference or departmental fairness.

principles.name: Implicit Assumption Challenge
principles.description: Sales saying customers 'buy on price' implicitly treats the product as 'a commodity.' Manufacturing saying they have 'low margins because we give it away' implies 'we work really hard to get this done, but they're giving it away.' Both assumptions need direct challenge.

principles.name: Evolving Expectations Acceptance
principles.description: 'Understanding from the owner's perspective what they think is going well and what is not going well. What do they want to happen short term and long term? Those answers change over the first couple of months, and that's okay.' Expectations naturally evolve and this is part of the process.

principles.name: Trends Over Reports
principles.description: 'I'm not looking for a particular report or anything like that, but what I am looking for is an understanding of the trend. So, where things are going in a lot of different categories.' Focus on directional movement rather than static snapshots.

principles.name: Bitching as Information Signal
principles.description: 'That's often the time when I start to hear a little bit more about the "bitching."' Owner complaints about employees provide valuable diagnostic information about organizational dynamics.

principles.name: Employee Self-Explanation Over Complaint Relay
principles.description: 'The goal is not to relay the complaints. The goal is to hear them explain how they see their role and how they hold themselves accountable.' Understanding employee perspective rather than prosecuting owner concerns.

principles.name: Third-Party Credibility for Role Clarity
principles.description: 'Coming from me, it's easier for them to take it from the owner.' External source provides neutrality that enables acceptance of role clarification documents.

principles.name: Roles and Responsibilities vs. Job Descriptions
principles.description: 'It's not a job description. It's roles and responsibilities, and it has some measurable outcomes. In many businesses, it's the first time they've ever seen it.' Focus on accountability and outcomes rather than task lists.

principles.name: Father's Work Ethic and Duty Foundation
principles.description: Father provided foundational influence through 'work ethic, sense of duty' - establishing core values around commitment and responsibility.

principles.name: Mother's Stoicism and Introvert Leadership Model
principles.description: Mother demonstrated 'stoicism and logic to some extent, and how you don't have to be an extrovert, and yet, people are still attracted to you.' This provided a model for non-extroverted leadership and influence.

principles.name: Boss's Work-Family Balance Excellence
principles.description: Limited boss 'did a great job of balancing work and family. Even while he traveled internationally, he worked really hard at it' - demonstrating that high-level professional success can coexist with family commitment.

principles.name: Aspirational Organization Standards
principles.Description: Limited boss 'remains the most organized person I've ever met at a level that I am comfortable with now that I will not achieve' - providing an aspirational but realistic benchmark for organizational excellence.

principles.name: Knowledge Seeking Time Distortion
principles.description: 'I will tend to lose track of time when I'm seeking knowledge, maybe a little bit too much time on that podcast or reading an article or a book or something like that. I don't balance that time very well.'

principles.name: Gap-Listening for Conversation Extension
principles.description: The most energizing work is 'learning about anybody's business. Anybody's business. Because all I'm listening for are gaps. Not to. Not to sell something. But I'm listening for gap to further the conversation.'

principles.name: Professionalism as Dedication, Not Rigidity
principles.description: 'The importance of moving your company toward professionalism and not just... I don't mean rigidity either, but I mean professionalism in the sense of a dedication that it's worth it, but it's really freaking heart. That's why they are where they are.'

principles.name: Scalable Discipline Principles
principles.description: Large organizations succeed through 'discipline that was non-negotiable for them.' Small businesses can adopt this discipline even without the same resources: 'we can't do it. We don't have the resources that they do. But they knew their numbers and they knew this and they knew that.'

principles.name: Decentralized Success Model Translation
principles.description: At The Limited, 'individual divisions just running their own business' provides a model for small businesses: 'I know how this $500 million business ran. They ran their own.' This shows scalable principles regardless of size.

principles.name: Authority Avoidance for Genuine Buy-In
principles.description: 'I get through a little bit because of the authority conferred upon me, but that's not how I wanted it to happen.' Preferring genuine understanding over compliance through positional power.

principles.name: Reframing from Obligation to Opportunity
principles.description: 'Continuing to reframe it from this, "This isn't what you have to do. This is what's right for the business." If you can save some time doing this, we can do this. This versus this is what you got to do because it's stupid.' Shifting from obligation/judgment to business value and opportunity.

principles.name: Fear-Aware Solution Design
principles.Description: Understanding that the warehouse manager 'is actually a little afraid of' computer technology, requiring solutions that account for emotional comfort as well as efficiency.

principles.name: Incremental Progress Over Perfection
principles.description: Moving from complex automation to 'more cut and paste' solutions that are 'simpler for him' rather than insisting on optimal technical solutions.

principles.name: Family Harmony Over Financial Maximization
principles.description: 'My goal is family harmony... We have to focus on family harmony first and the amount that you get paid second. I did not call me in for that.' Prioritizing relationship preservation over pure financial optimization in family business transitions.

principles.name: Range Over Fixed Number Strategy
principles.description: 'We can't go into this stuck on a number. We come up with a range. What feels good to you?' Using ranges to maintain negotiation flexibility and avoid positional bargaining.

principles.name: Middle Ground for Mutual Concession
principles.description: 'Family harmony becomes that middle ground where people ought to be willing to give a little bit. Both sides ought to be willing to give a little bit.' Creating shared values as foundation for compromise.

principles.name: Family Business Relationship Fragility Recognition
principles.description: 'I've seen too many family businesses where family members don't even talk to each other anymore.' Understanding long-term relationship costs of financial disputes in family contexts.

principles.name: Financial Quarterback Role
principles.description: Positioned as 'sort of that financial quarterback to just be behind the scenes... pulling together the information that is needed and help craft the strategy' - operational support rather than legal advocacy.

principles.name: Time as Emotional Processing Tool
principles.description: 'I try to just put time on my side. I try not to... If I cannot deal with it at that time, I don't... Because I think that's really hard to move someone from one side to the other.' Avoids direct confrontation of emotion in the moment.

principles.name: Non-Confrontational Emotional Management
principles.description: 'I don't know that I ever confront the emotion directly.' Instead, uses phrases like 'Okay, let's just stop. I'm not going to make a decision right now. I hear what you're saying. Let me go back and see if we can get it resolved that way.'

principles.name: Emotional Balloon Deflation Strategy
principles.description: With chronically emotional people, 'I gotta let that air out of the balloon because... Until he just obloviates whatever it is that he's doing... until he is finished bloviating, even though I'm not listening until he does that, he's not hearing me.'

principles.name: Extreme Detail as Emotional Counterbalance
principles.description: After letting emotional people vent, 'I sort of go over back to the extreme on the other side and get really detailed on what I need and when I need it. It's almost like the counterbalance to that.'

principles.name: Early Passion for Influence and Events
principles.description: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for playing soccer. I didn't have a passion for school. I had a passion for being class president.' Early drive focused on impact and involvement rather than pure leadership.

principles.name: Promotion-Focused vs. Work-Focused Passion
principles.description: 'I had a passion to be successful at the CPA firm... I was working to be promoted, but that was the passion. It wasn't about the work itself.' Motivation driven by advancement rather than intrinsic work satisfaction.

principles.name: Money and Prestige as Early Drivers
principles.description: 'That would have been the money and the prestige... because the goal was partner.' Clear acknowledgment of external validation and financial success as primary motivators.

principles.name: Role Model Disillusionment
principles.description: 'Very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' Success without lifestyle appeal led to career redirection.

principles.name: Uncertainty and Unpredictability Craving
principles.description: 'I missed the uncertainty of a client problem or a client picking up the phone and calling... Same shit, different day is a little bit extreme, but it was far more predictable than unpredictable.' Need for variety and surprise over stability.

principles.name: Family as Career Catalyst
principles.description: 'When the kids came along... I began to realize... The cost in hours required was not going to be worth it.' Children created values clarification that changed career trajectory.

principles.name: Connecting Dots as Critical Thinking Result
principles.description: 'Connecting the dots to me ends up being the result' of critical thinking, not the process itself. It represents the synthesis outcome rather than the method.

principles.name: Investigation Over Binary Reaction
principles.description: When sales decline despite adding staff, poor critical thinking leads to 'fire the first salesperson, or maybe you fire all the salespeople because it's always binary and it's anything but binary. Whereas if you employ critical thinking, then you are naturally doing much more investigation to understand the problem.'

principles.name: Modified Socratic Method as Toolbox Item
principles.description: 'I don't think of it as... It might be natural, but I don't know that about instinct as much as it's in my toolbox. It is a modification of the Socratic method. It's really all that it is. We're just trying to ask a question in response to your first question.'

principles.name: Questioning to Understand Origins
principles.description: 'The intention of the questioning is to figure out where the person's coming from. So, yeah, their assumptions, what caused them to say what they just said?' Focus on understanding reasoning behind statements.

principles.name: Fairness as Depth-Forcing Tool
principles.description: 'Fairness is how I get there' because 'you have to enforce fairness in that group' to force them to 'go deeper and not give me their surface-level BS complaints.' This requires them to 'think like an owner.'

principles.name: Owner-Perspective Requirement
principles.description: Fairness enforcement compels people to 'think like an owner' rather than from their narrow departmental perspective, leading to 'recognition of the bigger picture.'

principles.name: Self-Generated Silo Breaking
principles.description: 'If the leaders of the business have a wider lens to look at the business with rather than their own department, then there will absolutely be better decision-making because now we're knocking down some silos without saying that we're knocking down some silos because it has to come from them. Not me.'

principles.name: Physical Comfort as Guard-Lowering Tool
principles.description: 'There's always an element of making sure they're physically comfortable... I had my desk, and then I had a small round table with chairs. I always met unless I was pissed and then you met at the desk.' Physical environment signals relationship dynamic.

principles.name: Territory Advantage Through Location Choice
principles.description: 'If possible, I would go to that person. I'll go into their territory versus making them come to me.' Power dynamics shift when you enter someone else's space rather than summoning them.

principles.name: Self-Deprecation for Tension Relief
principles.description: 'During the conversation, there's usually, like, you know, I just get into some self deprecating comments and stuff to try to just ease the tension.' Using vulnerability to create comfort and authenticity.

principles.name: Desk vs. Table Meeting Signal
principles.description: Meeting at the desk when 'pissed' versus the round table for normal conversations creates clear power dynamic signals through furniture choice.

principles.name: Two or Three Priorities Mental Framework
principles.description: 'I don't have it mapped out, but I do have two or three priorities in my head at all times.' Operating with a small, manageable set of concurrent focus areas rather than detailed plans.

principles.name: Financial Analysis as Starting Point Standard
principles.description: 'I'm almost always in what is on the front of their mind at the beginning, it's my financial background. So I want to deliver for a couple of reasons. One, it's what I do. And two, it is their weakness.' Leveraging core strength to address client weakness consistently.

principles.name: Gross Margin Concentration Insight
principles.description: 'The first victory was explaining to the owner that 50% of his gross margin dollars come from only a third of his inventory.' Revealing hidden profit concentration patterns that owners don't see.

principles.name: Cash Understanding as Primary Purpose
principles.description: 'I always use it for the primary purpose, and that is to understand their cash. The ins and outs of cash because I have to be comfortable with it, and they have to be comfortable with it because some people may be running out of cash and not even know.'

principles.name: Net Income vs. Cash Mistake Recognition
principles.description: 'Net income is the same as cash. That's the number one mistake nonfinancial people make, without a doubt.' Understanding the fundamental confusion between profit reporting and cash flow reality.

principles.name: No Full Map Transparency
principles.description: 'No' - clients don't have access to the full strategic map because 'I just keep jumping around and don't really want to lay it out for...' The path is intentionally not revealed in its entirety.

principles.name: Non-Linear Path Reality
principles.description: The path to profitability is not linear, and next steps are determined dynamically: 'Very much' figuring out the next step while in the current step, informed by deeper business understanding.

principles.name: Discovery Session Skepticism
principles.description: 'Marketers love to have these discovery sessions, which are 90 minutes of bullshit because all you're hearing is the owner's perspective of the business. That's not how things get done.' Formal discovery processes provide limited real insight.

principles.name: Deeper Business Understanding Than Owners
principles.description: 'I end up learning more about how things really get done than the owner in many times, so it's hard for me to know what the next step is until I understand the business better.' Operational reality differs from owner perception.

principles.name: Experience-Informed Intuitive Navigation
principles.description: 'I don't know, experience' combined with understanding 'how things really get done' guides next step selection without predetermined roadmaps.

principles.name: Team Collaboration as Third Pillar
principles.description: 'If I think about my best hires... there's some sort of either, collaborator or team, you know, teamwork, approach that's embedded in the personality, you know, not a loaner.' This adds to critical thinking and business acumen as core hiring criteria.

principles.name: Linear Answers as Guardedness Signal
principles.description: 'What I'm listening for is if it's like every answer is very linear, it just comes across as guarded. So I end up trusting them less because now they're just telling me what I want to hear.' Overly polished responses indicate inauthentic communication.

principles.name: Nonverbal Cue Baseline Assessment
principles.description: Standard awareness of 'nonverbal cues of whether they're nervous or whether they're looking away when they answer, or fidgety' but these are less important than communication style assessment.

principles.name: Benevolent Dictatorship with Collaborative Tools
principles.description: 'I get the best results when I am the benevolent dictator and using my collaborative skills to pull the team together.' This represents the integration of authority with collaborative methodology.

principles.name: Repetition as Critical Thinking Reinforcement
principles.description: 'One of the tools that I use very consciously is repetition... I'm pretty sure the next time that issue comes around, they're not going to remember... So I keep coming back and saying, "Okay, now, remember what we talked about last week?"'

principles.name: Critical Thinking Limitation Recognition
principles.description: 'I can't turn someone into a strong critical thinker.' Acknowledging the fundamental limitation that critical thinking ability has natural boundaries that coaching cannot overcome.

principles.name: Process Breakdown with Check-ins
principles.description: 'Break it up into as many parts as you can and put in some check-in points along the way to where you're literally just checking their thinking... Like, stop. Don't do this until you've checked with me.'

principles.name: Intuitive Challenge with Fact Request
principles.description: 'That doesn't feel right, and here's why it doesn't feel right. So, if you have some facts that will change my mind, I'm very open to it, but until then, I'm not there... What can you do to bring me some facts to help me understand where you are?'

principles.name: Six Core Business Benefits
principles.description: Primary value delivered: 'Financial clarity, sounding board for the owner, the person who ensures the execution of the owner's wishes, improved profitability, improved accountability' plus 'a happier team.' These represent the complete value proposition.

principles.name: Happier Team as Afterthought Recognition
principles.description: 'Yeah, a happier team' added after initial five benefits, suggesting this outcome is valued but not always consciously positioned as primary benefit.

principles.name: Trusted Advisor Continuity
principles.description: 'In some ways, I think it's no different than coming right out of college into a public accounting firm. I was still working with business owners in a much more specialized capacity, but I was still advising, and I was acting as a trusted advisor.' Career consistency in advisory role.

principles.name: Unconscious Career Choice
principles.description: 'I don't even know that it was conscious' about choosing accounting, suggesting career evolution happened organically rather than through strategic planning.

principles.name: Logic and Symmetry Appeal
principles.description: 'Probably the symmetry of dividends equalling credits and the logic of it. So, I got it.' Attraction to systematic, logical frameworks that have clear rules and balance.

principles.name: Practical Field Selection
principles.description: 'Probably at the time, I knew it was a very solid field to go into.' Career choice influenced by stability and security considerations alongside intellectual appeal.

principles.name: Self-Employment Influence as Foundation
principles.description: 'My dad being self-employed was a factor. I think seeing a couple of brothers who own businesses was a factor.' These early exposures to entrepreneurship shaped fundamental perspectives on work and autonomy.

principles.name: Intentional Problem Creation for Stimulation
principles.description: 'I can get... I did get bored easily to the point where if I had the opportunity to break something, I would. That way, I had something else to do or to push just to go do something new.' Boredom drives destructive behavior to create new challenges.

principles.name: Corporate Cycle Monotony Recognition
principles.description: 'I view company life as pretty much a 12-month cycle, and not that much new happens year to year... You're doing the same shit every 12 months. You're just maybe doing it with more people, fewer people, bigger budget, smaller budget. You're still doing the same shit.'

principles.name: Need for External Stimulation
principles.description: 'I need that phone to ring because it's nothing to do.' The requirement for external, unpredictable inputs to maintain engagement and energy.

principles.name: Owner as Own Roadblock Recognition
principles.description: 'She remains the roadblock two months later, even giving stuff to me that I should be doing. So she just puts it off, puts it off, puts it off.' Understanding that owners often prevent their own progress despite hiring help.

principles.name: Urgent vs. Important Distinction
principles.description: 'Some of which might be urgent, most are not. They just happen to be weighing on her mind and probably represent some future path to revenue, some extremely undefined path to future revenue.' Mental burden doesn't equal actual priority.

principles.name: True Priorities vs. Revenue Impact
principles.description: 'I'm just listening for what the true priorities are, not necessarily based on revenue impact but based on what it's going to take to get her working on the right things to get her out of the mud.' Priority assessment based on operational effectiveness rather than revenue potential.

principles.name: Self-Discovery Through Questioning
principles.description: 'I just start asking questions about each of those so-called priorities. I try to let her talk it through so that she realizes that some of them aren't priorities.' Facilitation over direction for genuine understanding.

principles.name: Time Freedom as Priority Test
principles.description: 'What if this week we did nothing more than number two and number three? What impact would that have?' Using time liberation as a metric for identifying true priorities that enable higher-value work.

principles.name: Business-First Decision Framework
principles.description: 'Acting in the best interest of the business is the best way to act.' This represents a core mental model for decision-making that prioritizes business sustainability over other considerations.

principles.name: Financial-Customer Balance Recognition
principles.description: 'He tends to put the customer first, regardless of the financial implications... it's a balance. It's not always about the financial decision. It's not always about the customer. There's a balance that needs to be struck between it.' Business decisions require balancing competing priorities.

principles.name: Recognition vs. Learning Distinction
principles.description: 'I probably should say recognize, because he's not a... He's a bright guy.' The issue isn't intelligence or capability but awareness of principles already within reach.

principles.name: Higher Standards Challenge
principles.description: 'He doesn't ask more of himself or the team. I don't know. I don't know where I'd go with that. That's tougher.' Identifying the need for higher performance standards while acknowledging the difficulty of instilling this mindset.

principles.name: Being Right Isn't Always the Goal
principles.description: 'Heads and shoulders above all is... Being right isn't always the goal.' This represents a fundamental shift from rightness-based decision making to outcome-based flexibility.

principles.name: Rigidity as Professional Liability
principles.description: Past approach was to 'base decisions and actions on what is right' which caused internal fury and detachment when things seemed wrong. This rigidity 'would just set me up to fail' and 'end up pissing her off because I wasn't doing it her way, even though it was wrong.'

principles.name: Client Method Acceptance
principles.description: 'I literally don't worry about it with clients anymore. They're go to do' what they want to do. This acceptance prevents the internal conflict that previously caused detachment and relationship damage.

principles.name: Job Security Through Flexibility
principles.description: Learning flexibility 'in part, for job security' represents a practical adaptation where survival required abandoning rigid righteousness in favor of relationship preservation.

principles.name: External Reliance Activation
principles.description: 'I have to know someone is relying on me. I can't just do it. Not that I can't do it for myself, but for me to reach a level of intensity of not only quality but just thought process, I need to know that the output will be used by someone else.'

principles.name: Root Cause Over Surface Solutions
principles.description: 'Root cause... You'll never get to the root cause in the first conversation, obviously. But even two or three conversations in, you still haven't drilled down into the core issue.' Emphasis on deep causal understanding rather than quick fixes.

principles.name: Tool-Throwing as False Victory
principles.description: 'What a lot of people in my position do is just throw ideas and tools out to try to solve those surface-level issues and then declare victory. But it hasn't necessarily built a stronger company.' Critique of superficial consulting approaches.

principles.name: Multi-Conversation Root Cause Discovery
principles.description: Root cause analysis requires patience across 'two or three conversations' or more, rejecting the pressure for immediate problem identification and solution.

principles.name: Fractional Advisor Identity
principles.description: 'It's that fractional advisor. You know, COO CFO.' Current role conception as hybrid operational and financial leadership rather than pure consulting.

principles.name: Good People Over Perfect Fit
principles.description: 'Everyone likes to run around saying, right people on the bus in the right seats. What has changed? A lot for me is you just need good people and give them direction. You don't need to spend as much time as you do trying to make sure there's an exact fit.'

principles.name: Environment-Driven Self-Management
principles.description: 'The right person in the right environment becomes self-managing over time if you allow it' - good people naturally adapt and become autonomous when given proper conditions.

principles.name: Value-Based vs. Task-Based Recruitment
principles.description: 'Every single time, I would throw out the tasks and I would write about the importance or the value because that's what will attract people.' Focus on meaning rather than specific duties in job descriptions.

principles.name: Critical Thinking as Universal Currency
principles.description: 'Critical thinking is everything. Business acumen is really important. If you get those right, you can put that person in almost any role and they'll do well.' These core capabilities matter more than specific skills.

principles.name: Skills Tests Skepticism
principles.description: 'When I come across someone who relies on a bunch of skills tests to decide whether they want to hire the right person, I don't think that they've changed their odds of success at all.' Technical assessments don't predict success.

principles.name: Daily Financial Foundation Reliance
principles.description: 'I go back to the financial foundation almost every day, whether I want to or not.' The accounting/CPA background provides constant practical value regardless of conscious intent to use it.

principles.name: Small Business Owner Knowledge Gap Recognition
principles.description: The accounting foundation is valuable 'because it's knowledge that most small business owners don't have.' This creates a consistent competitive advantage and value proposition.

principles.name: Elevated Status Through Association
principles.description: Working at Arthur Anderson provided 'elevated status' in Cincinnati because 'if you worked there, you had an elevated status.' This early credibility foundation influences ongoing professional positioning.

principles.name: Room Reading and Depth Calibration
principles.description: 'First, it's reading the room, and if I sense tension, then I don't go deep as quickly. I tend to stay on the surface and ask really easy questions.' This requires having advance knowledge of where tensions exist.

principles.name: Stereotype Acknowledgment for Unity
principles.description: Address how different departments are 'stereotypically perceived' openly 'in front of everyone' to 'put everyone on the same level, that we are literally all in this together.' This involves speaking to how 'everyone else in the company is saying to them, even though I don't work there.'

principles.name: Sacred First-Time Moments
principles.description: Recognizing when groups are coming together 'for the first time they've ever done anything like that' or 'the first time they had really come together to talk about the future of the business' and treating these moments with appropriate significance.

principles.name: Creative Owners Focus
principles.description: 'I help creative owners get back to doing what they were doing that made the business great.' Core mission focused on enabling founders to return to their strengths.

principles.name: Switzerland Neutrality Model
principles.description: 'I am Switzerland if the employee... I freely admit I am being paid by the owner, but I work for the company, and I'm going to do the... I'm going to work in the best interest of the company, not the owner.' Neutral position between owner and employees.

principles.name: Leadership Term Rejection
principles.description: 'I won't say leadership because I don't think that word means anything anymore. It's just squishy, and people just run around saying that they're practicing leadership.' Preferring concrete terms like accountability and responsibility.

principles.name: Accountability and Responsibility Over Leadership
principles.description: 'I help people become more accountable, and I help them take on more responsibility... I work to figure out who owns what in the organization and who is capable of taking on more and helping them get it.'

principles.name: Early Passion for Influence and Events
principles.description: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for being class president.' Early drive to shape outcomes and be central to important activities.

principles.name: Partner Role Model Disillusionment
principles.description: 'Very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' Success without lifestyle appeal led to career redirection.

principles.name: Critical Thinking as Umbrella Skill
principles.description: 'If you have high critical thinking skills, you are a problem solver. But it's not just about solving problems. It's just how you look at things.' Critical thinking encompasses multiple cognitive abilities including problem-solving.

principles.name: Emotional Intelligence as Critical Thinking Component
principles.description: 'I'm tempted to put emotional intelligence under there. I'd probably have to think about that one a little bit longer, though.' This represents an unconventional but potentially valid connection.

principles.name: Critical Thinking vs. Moonshot Tension
principles.description: 'Too much critical thinking could get in the way because your logic brain is shutting down too much of the "what if"... moonshot goals probably don't sit well with a critical thinker because I can't envision it, but I certainly can't figure out how to get there.'

principles.name: Uncovering vs. Creating in Dot Connection
principles.description: 'I would suspect it has more to do with uncovering what's already there. It's your ability to draw conclusions, not out of thin air, but by seeing relationships that others don't see.' However, 'I think you can create a relationship. Sure.'

principles.name: Concreteness as Critical Thinking Characteristic
principles.description: Critical thinking is 'more about being concrete' rather than being inflexible or impatient with big ideas.

principles.name: Paint the Future, Let Them Choose
principles.description: When difficult personnel decisions are needed, 'I just painted the picture that there is a future, and she's not part of it. I allowed her to think about it and come back.' This preserves dignity while achieving necessary outcomes.

principles.name: Public Ownership of Difficult Decisions
principles.description: Ensure difficult decisions appear to be the person's choice publicly - 'It was all publicly... It was all her decision. I was the only one who could make that happen. It was entirely my decision.' The benevolent dictator takes responsibility while preserving dignity.

principles.name: Negotiator Role Between Competing Interests
principles.description: When operations and HR conflict over discipline, act 'almost like a negotiator going back and forth between ops and HR. Both of them knew I could just make a decision to be done with it, but that's not how I wanted to do it. I just wanted to reach the best decision for the business.'

principles.name: The Unexpected Call as Ultimate Validation
principles.description: What would be most missed in retirement is 'the unexpected phone call' - calls about deeply personal business decisions like divorce from business partners or firing someone for the first time.

principles.name: Guidance Over Direction
principles.description: The value provided is 'not to tell them what to do, but to give them guidance so that they feel better and a little bit more confident about whatever it is, whatever that next step is.'

principles.name: Trusted Advisor for Life-Changing Moments
principles.description: Being the person someone calls for guidance on major life transitions - from business partnership divorces to first-time firings - represents the deepest level of professional trust and reliance.

principles.name: Empathetic Experience Recognition
principles.description: 'I know that there are things that they wish were better in some way, and I've... Chances are, I've experienced some of what they're feeling.' This creates the foundation for meaningful help.

principles.name: Solution-Oriented vs Answer-Oriented Help
principles.description: 'What energizes me is not to give them an answer, but to give them a possible solution.' This distinction between definitive answers and exploratory possibilities drives engagement.

principles.name: Reliance as Validation
principles.description: 'What I really want... But I want them to rely on me.' This desire for reliance serves as validation that 'my previous work has helped them. Chances are, they want more. It's not about whether they want more to pay more. They want more.'

principles.name: Resistance Detection and Classification
principles.description: 'I'm listening for resistance to whatever I'm saying' and determining 'whether that resistance is passing any logical test or whether it's pure emotion.' This applies equally to agreement: 'are you just agreeing with me on a logical side or on an emotional side?'

principles.name: Logic-Side Landing Requirement
principles.description: 'I need to know that you're landing on the logic side. If I will probably dismiss what you have to say from the emotional side.' This represents a clear hierarchy of reasoning validity.

principles.name: Critical Thinking Improvement Ceiling
principles.description: 'You can teach critical thinking... But if you're lousy, you can't become excellent. You can improve.' There are natural limits to how much critical thinking ability can be developed through training.

principles.name: Poor Critical Thinking as Dot Connection Failure
principles.description: 'To me, it's an inability to connect the dots' combined with drawing 'incorrect conclusions based upon either inferring facts which aren't there or based on emotion.'

principles.name: Problem-Solving as Critical Thinking Subset
principles.description: 'I think of problem-solving as a subset of critical thinking skills' because critical thinking has broader applications beyond specific problem-solving contexts.

principles.name: Critical Thinking as Information Immunity
principles.description: Critical thinking 'enables you to go through an election season and not get crazy from the ads. Because the left is as full of shit as the right... I don't act on it because they haven't given me enough information to draw the conclusion they want me to draw.'

principles.name: Verify Claims Through Independent Analysis
principles.description: 'Until I prove it, I'm not going to say that you're wrong. I'm not going to say that you're right. I just have to know for myself that it's true.' Independent verification of claimed performance metrics, even from reputable sources.

principles.name: Advisor Role in Growth Moderation
principles.description: When owner gets excited about scaling ('why don't we just increase it 20% every month'), respond with 'Well, let's just slow down a little bit. Let's just be a little bit more deliberate with that and make sure we understand what we're doing.'

principles.name: Framing Role as Company Enablement
principles.description: To warehouse manager: 'Dan really thinks he's got the formula figured out and he really wants to grow. I said my job is to make sure the rest of the company can keep up with his plans.' Positioning as supporting growth rather than controlling it.

principles.name: Urgent vs. Important Priority Correction
principles.description: 'We have a priority problem here... We're not working on what's important. We're working on what's urgent. All day long.' Distinguishing between crisis management and strategic focus.

principles.name: Badgering for Delegation Acceptance
principles.description: 'The way I'm getting there is I am badger her with texts and requests for meetings... Just give it to me.' Persistent pressure to force owners to delegate tasks they shouldn't be doing.

principles.name: Intuition Recognition Without Action
principles.description: 'I will often come to an instant conclusion. But I know that I don't act on it. So, I may have a thought, but I don't... I don't express it typically because I'm still in the mode of just gathering more, so I do not act a lot on intuition.'

principles.name: Intuitive Process Selection
principles.description: Intuition operates at the process level in crisis situations where 'there's no plan in front of you.' It guides whether to 'blur out something and solve the problem' or recognize 'I need to get more information, and I need these people to... I need someone else to help me make this decision.'

principles.name: Professional Circle Exposure as Learning Catalyst
principles.description: 'The exposure of working with various attorneys in thirty different states... you just get to know them, and you go out to dinner and things like that. You just learn a lot, not about law and taxes, but in everything. You learn from them.' This broad professional exposure creates knowledge beyond core competencies.

principles.name: Judgment Over Technical Skills Application
principles.description: At the Limited, 'being a CPA wasn't that important... It was more about just taking that. I was making a lot of their judgments on appeals and litigation and everything. So it was more about judgment than anything versus advising a client.'

principles.name: Big Company Perspective as Small Business Advantage
principles.description: 'I can bring them a big company and big CPA firm perspective that they otherwise don't get.' The combination of large organization experience applied to small business contexts creates unique value.

principles.name: Responsibility Progression Through Specialization
principles.description: Career progression from 'super specialist' at big CPA firm where 'I was a step removed from helping them' to Limited where 'I'm still a specialist, but I have greater responsibility.'

principles.name: Critical Thinking as Information Reception Plus Processing
principles.description: 'Critical thinking... is the ability to accept information and connect the dots for decision-making. So, what is really interesting about critical thinking is how you receive information is just as important as how you process it.'

principles.name: Filter-Driven Reality Distortion
principles.description: 'His filter was so pronounced that we could sit next to each other and hear someone speak, and we would hear things completely differently... his filter caused him to hear things that are always negatively and things that could always go wrong.'

principles.name: 80/20 Objective-Subjective Reception Ratio
principles.description: Optimal information reception is 'probably 80% objective and 20% subjective' - mostly accepting information as provided while maintaining some personal filter.

principles.name: Emotional Intelligence as Reception Foundation
principles.description: Good information receivers have 'a very strong emotional intelligence. So they're not reacting right away. They're willing to accept and process or hear it and process it before they accept it rather than just react.'

principles.name: Passion for Problem-Based Helping
principles.description: 'I just help someone has a problem... When we're finished talking about it or I go off and do something and come back to them, they feel better for it. It's not about giving an answer.' Passion centered on providing relief and improvement rather than solution delivery.

principles.name: Teaching as Career Analog
principles.description: 'The closest thing that comes to mind is teaching... you're not helping with a current problem but you're taking all of your experience and helping them to understand the problem and maybe avoid them down the road.' Similar helping function with prevention focus.

principles.name: Limited Current Interests
principles.description: 'Being a right-wing reactionary is really important to me on a daily basis... My interest, even in sports, is waning a little bit. Outside of family, I read and stuff... Don't have any other interests.' Narrow range of current passions beyond work and family.

principles.name: Evolution from Giving Answers to Leading to Solutions
principles.description: 'Earlier... I thought help meant giving answers. Help really means leading people to a better solution.' Fundamental shift in helping philosophy from directive to facilitative approach.

principles.name: Clarity Before Confidence Sequence
principles.description: 'I give the owner confidence and clarity... It's strike that clarity then confidence. They have to have the clarity first of why they're doing it, because if there's this much hesitation, it gets blown up and whatever change that we agreed needs to happen.'

principles.name: Evidence Confirmation of Known Problems
principles.description: The investigation with phone logs and tracking 'was just confirming what he already knew' - providing data to support decisions they already sense need to be made.

principles.name: Process Over Outcome Confidence Building
principles.description: 'He knew he had to do it, he wanted to do it, but he didn't know how, which really was just saying I'm still nervous. Even though I have the clarity, I don't have the confidence yet.' Confidence comes from understanding the process, not just the need.

principles.name: 90-Minute Confidence Investment
principles.description: Spending 90 minutes on vacation to talk through the process until the owner was ready to act, resulting in 'He has not looked back since. He has felt no regret.'

principles.name: Revenue Quality Over Quantity
principles.description: 'Not every sale is a good sale depending upon your business' - understanding that revenue growth must include customer selectivity and pricing strategy, not just volume.

principles.name: Gross Margin as Overlooked Driver
principles.description: 'Most businesses don't pay enough attention to gross margin. They accept the price that they're charging because that's what they think the market allows, and their costs are their costs because the supplier has told them that's just what it is.'

principles.name: Above-the-Line vs Below-the-Line Focus
principles.description: 'The real drivers are above the line more so than below the line. Any business can find 10% or 20% savings in overhead easily, but that's not driving your business anywhere. It's really about the revenue and the cost of sale.'

principles.name: Paper Clips Fallacy
principles.description: Businesses 'spend all their time trying to not by paper clips this month or cut back on supplies so that they could make their number' instead of focusing on major profit drivers.

principles.name: Champion of the Overlooked
principles.description: Immediate focus on 'the number twos and number threes at the company because they are overlooked. They are seriously overlooked. That's where I go right away.' These people need external validation: 'Sometimes, they just need someone on the outside to say, "This is what you need." She needs more.'

principles.name: Teacher vs Collaborator Role Differentiation
principles.description: With number twos and threes, 'I can play a little bit more of the role of the teacher, whereas with the owner, I have to be more of that collaborator than a... Than a teacher.' Both represent 'different applications of knowledge.'

principles.name: Incomplete Ideas as Valuable Perspective
principles.description: Number twos and threes 'often have some pretty interesting ideas. Not fully formed ideas because they may not see the whole picture, but what they have to contribute is an important perspective that the owner may not have.'

principles.name: Person Decisions as Core Business Issue
principles.description: 'Most often, the decision is what do I do about this person? That's the pain point... that becomes a core issue from the person I'm working with.' People decisions represent the fundamental challenge in most business situations.

principles.name: Collaboration as Decision Architecture Foundation
principles.description: 'I know it's a tired word, but it still comes back to collaboration.' Despite overuse, collaboration remains the core approach to major decision-making processes.

principles.name: Owner Recognition Over Planning as Offsite Purpose
principles.description: 'I do that so that the owner either remembers or recognizes that the people on their team have some really good ideas and you need to listen to them instead of just running around in a frenzy.' Team meetings designed for owner education rather than planning output.

principles.name: Tactics vs. Team Health Hierarchy
principles.description: 'The pricing stuff and profit, those are tactics... the only way the company becomes healthier, and it doesn't matter what its problem is, it's only going to help become healthier if those key people in the owner become much more of a team.' Team cohesion as foundation for all other improvements.

principles.name: Team Exhaustion Recognition
principles.description: 'There is no doubt that she's wearing them down as well.' Understanding that owner dysfunction affects entire team energy and effectiveness.

principles.name: Human Element Integration
principles.description: Drucker 'never let go of the human element of anything that he did, and he still doesn't seem to get very much credit for that' - emphasizing the importance of maintaining human considerations in business analysis.

principles.name: Focus on the Real
principles.description: 'He focused on the real because what I learned from him was what's the real?' This represents looking beyond surface appearances to understand underlying drivers and actual customer needs.

principles.name: Predictive Analysis Through Real Understanding
principles.description: Drucker's 'ability to look into the future' demonstrated through writing 'an article about department stores in the seventies, telling us why they're not going to survive' by understanding real underlying changes rather than surface trends.

principles.name: Real Issue Recognition Over Surface Focus
principles.description: Department stores 'kept focusing on fashion' while 'everything became about time' due to changing demographics. 'Target and Costco came because they addressed the real issue of time' rather than the perceived issue of fashion.

principles.name: Early Leadership Reality - Not Everyone Wants to be Led
principles.description: Class president experience taught 'at an early age... that you can't lead all people? Some people don't want to be led.' This fundamental leadership reality was learned through direct experience in high school.

principles.name: Team Success Over Personal Gain
principles.description: As soccer coach, 'you're trying to figure out how to orchestrate this mess for the greater good. It wasn't for my greater good. It was really for the team's success.' Leadership focused on collective outcomes rather than personal benefit.

principles.name: Collaboration-Authority Balance
principles.description: 'If you're a coach and you're not a collaborator, I suspect that you're not very successful.' However, 'sometimes, you had to put your foot down and all that. So, that's that. That balance.' Leadership requires both collaborative and authoritative approaches.

principles.name: Authority Despite Age/Experience Disadvantage
principles.description: As 'a freshman coach to 22 women, most of whom were older than me, it was quite telling' - learning to lead people with more experience and maturity created early lessons in authority without traditional credentials.

principles.name: Universal Strength Claims Pattern
principles.description: 'Everyone says they're responsive. Everyone says they're adaptable. Everyone says that they value teamwork and or collaborators, or they engage in consultative selling... then you get into dedication and throw away stuff like that.' Common self-descriptions across companies.

principles.name: Responsiveness Skepticism
principles.description: 'I think they're full of shit about responsiveness... It's hard for me to know. I don't know the company that well.' Default skepticism about the most commonly claimed strength.

principles.name: Truth Secondary to Consensus
principles.description: 'I want team consensus... Even if this has happened, even if I don't believe it, not my plan.' Team agreement matters more than factual accuracy in the SWOT process.

principles.name: Personalized Collaboration Orchestration
principles.description: Effective collaboration requires evaluating 'that person's arguments based on how well you understand their thinking style.' Some people 'go off very quickly' requiring processing adjustments, while others 'literally need to go away and then come back.' This personalized approach is 'part of the orchestration.'

principles.name: Emotional Intelligence Through Information Exchange
principles.description: Emotional intelligence manifests 'through the give and take of the collaborative process' where the focus is on 'knowing that they're free to say whatever is on their mind as we try to figure out a solution to the crisis.'

principles.name: Answer-Timing Wisdom
principles.description: Recognizing when 'an answer is not necessarily what's needed right now because we don't have enough information,' even when 'they may be coming for an answer.'

principles.name: Crisis Perspective Management
principles.description: When crisis hits, 'communicate through words or behavior that we're not looking at something that is the end of the world. It is important and it needs to be dealt with, but we're going to take a beat to make sure that we understand it and then move forward.'

principles.name: Collaborative Crisis Response
principles.description: Crisis flow state involves 'go into collaborator mode' where 'I'm not really head down trying to do it myself, but I'm trying to take in as much information as I can on the crisis.' For crises, 'it tends not to be directive.'

principles.name: SWOT as Weakness-Focused Exercise
principles.description: 'It's all about weaknesses.' The entire SWOT analysis is designed to identify and address organizational weaknesses rather than building on strengths or pursuing opportunities.

principles.name: Sandbox Ownership Model
principles.description: 'You own the sandbox... no one else is allowed in your sandbox' including the owner. Clear responsibility boundaries that prevent interference once roles are defined.

principles.name: Strategy as Luxury for Well-Functioning Organizations
principles.description: 'Most companies couldn't be strategic. If their life depended on it, they would fail. They're not doing that well now because of the stuff that's in their way.' Strategy requires operational excellence first.

principles.name: Root Cause Drilling in Weaknesses
principles.description: 'I try to get them to drill down to the root cause pretty hard... it's not about an answer, it's about having the open discussion with everyone on your team.' Process over solution focus.

principles.name: Collective Responsibility for All Priorities
principles.description: 'Everyone who attended the meeting is now responsible for all of these... If someone asks you to help, you have to help. It's not optional.' Shared accountability beyond individual assignments.

principles.name: On Track vs. Off Track Binary Assessment
principles.description: 'The entire focus is it's on track or it's off track. That's all we need to know.' Eliminating debate and complexity in status reporting.

principles.name: Family Over Career Priority Decision
principles.description: 'I was clearly putting the family ahead of my career. What I should just say is what I thought was best for the family.' This represents a fundamental values-based decision that shaped future operating principles.

principles.name: Big Company Breathlessness Recognition
principles.description: 'I'd been there nine years, and I was breathless. So, I turned down other opportunities because my whole family was here' - recognizing when career progression conflicts with personal well-being and family priorities.

principles.name: Long-term Thinking Over Short-term Gain
principles.description: 'I thought in the long run, the kids would thrive back here or do better' - prioritizing long-term family outcomes over immediate career advancement opportunities.

principles.name: Finality and Root-Setting
principles.description: 'Moving back felt final, meaning I never put down roots in Columbus. So, that's a very local feeling.' The decision represented commitment to place and community rather than career mobility.

principles.name: Lincoln's Complex Leadership Admiration
principles.description: 'I still admire Lincoln. I just can't figure it out. I just love reading or hearing stories about even the "Team of Rivals" and the skill required to manage that cabinet and the Civil War and everything is just phenomenal.' Lincoln represents complex leadership under extreme pressure.

principles.name: Rejection of Management Fads
principles.description: 'I don't believe in any management tool or fed. Whereas maybe ten years ago I would have like this like we got to do the balanced scorecard or you know what, whatever.' Evolution away from standardized management approaches.

principles.name: Owner-Centric Custom Solutions
principles.description: 'The best plan is the plan that starts with a recognition of the owner's strengths and weaknesses and then you just borrow. You just borrow and put something together that fits because it has to feel like theirs.'

principles.name: Ownership vs. Imposition for Sustainability
principles.description: 'If it always feels like someone else's, they do it for a year and then they quit all the time.' Solutions must feel authentic to the person implementing them for long-term success.

principles.name: Months-Long Process Acceptance
principles.description: 'I don't think I do it any differently than any other issue because I'm not looking for the quick fix anyway. If most of the issues are people-related, none of that gets fixed quickly anyway. It's months.' Inherent expectation that meaningful change takes extended time.

principles.name: Chipping Away Over Solution Delivery
principles.description: 'The process is much more about chipping away than just bringing a solution and saying, "Here you go. This will solve all of your problems."' Incremental progress methodology rather than comprehensive solutions.

principles.name: Employee Trust Through One-on-One Engagement
principles.description: 'That involves establishing trust with the employees, which means dealing with them one on one without the owner present, and in doing so, acknowledging some of the inconsistencies that I see in the business.'

principles.name: Balanced Acknowledgment and Defense
principles.description: 'When they just start bitching, I do come back and I jump back and forth between acknowledging some of the inconsistencies and defending the owner... Reminding them that the owner is the one who has risk.' Maintaining neutrality while educating about different perspectives.

principles.name: Owner Description Accuracy Skepticism
principles.description: 'Pulling in the description I heard from the owner, which is rarely accurate, but I'll ask questions to try to verify that.' Default assumption that owner descriptions need verification through employee perspectives.

principles.name: Unconscious Approachability as Core Identity
principles.description: Being described as 'very approachable' was a revelation - 'I had never thought about that before... I don't know that I had ever been actually described as very approachable. I don't know, that's always stuck with me.' This represents an unconscious core trait.

principles.name: Innate Insight and Dot-Connection
principles.description: 'I've always been insightful, and people just rely on that. They just rely on me to connect the dots for them.' This is presented as a fundamental, unchanging aspect of identity.

principles.name: Loyalty Creation Under Adversity
principles.description: Ability to 'create an incredibly loyal group of people' even in hostile environments where 'all the parents invent reasons to hate you' demonstrates leadership under pressure.

principles.name: Profit as Managed Goal vs. Natural Result
principles.description: 'I do have a greater focus on profit than ever before because earlier, my focus was more about profit as a result, not something to be managed.' Evolution from passive to active profit management approach.

principles.name: Profit-Cash Equivalency Understanding
principles.description: 'I have realized that profit and cash are essentially the same thing. What is holding them back from their dreams, their employees' dreams, and just a better life is a lack of understanding of what it takes to create profit.'

principles.name: Multi-Area Continuous Improvement
principles.description: 'You're not going to hit a home run on any one of those areas and declare victory. You're always improving each one of those areas. That is what creates a better opportunity for profit.' No single breakthrough creates lasting profit improvement.

principles.name: Profit as Pressure Relief
principles.description: Better profit management 'relieves so much of the pressure that the owner is feeling' - profit isn't just financial but psychological relief.

principles.name: Evolution from Single-Variable Focus
principles.Description: 'When I was younger, I would get fixated on just revenue, expenses, taxes, or something like that. It's much more complex to get there.' Moving from narrow focus to systems thinking.

principles.name: Evolution Over Events
principles.description: 'It's not an event... It was a series of small steps that added up to create a big impact.' Profit improvement happens through accumulated incremental changes rather than breakthrough moments.

principles.name: How Businesses Really Work Understanding
principles.description: 'Because they don't know how businesses really work.' Deep operational understanding as the foundation for effective consulting, distinguishing from theoretical knowledge.

principles.name: Big Ideas Get Killed
