examples.content: When asked what he might add to critical thinking and business acumen as hiring pillars, Dan identifies team collaboration: 'if I think about my best hires... there's some sort of either, collaborator or team, you know, teamwork, approach that's embedded in the personality, you know, not a loaner.'

examples.name: Detecting Guardedness Through Linear Responses
examples.content: Beyond standard nonverbal cues, Dan listens for 'if it's like every answer is very linear, it just comes across as guarded. So I end up trusting them less because now they're just telling me what I want to hear.' This overly polished response style signals inauthentic communication.

examples.name: Benevolent Dictatorship Definition
examples.content: When asked to clarify the relationship between collaboration and dictatorship, Dan explains 'I get the best results when I am the benevolent dictator and using my collaborative skills to pull the team together,' showing how authority and collaboration work together rather than in opposition.

examples.name: Repetition for Critical Thinking Reinforcement
examples.content: Dan uses 'repetition' consciously because when people reach conclusions through guided thinking, 'the next time that issue comes around, they're not going to remember... They're not going to go back and connect the dots again.' So he keeps 'coming back and saying, "Okay, now, remember what we talked about last week?"'

examples.name: Intuitive Challenge Method
examples.content: When working with poor critical thinkers in domains where he lacks expertise, Dan says 'that doesn't feel right, and here's why it doesn't feel right. So, if you have some facts that will change my mind, I'm very open to it, but until then, I'm not there, so we can't move forward.' He pushes responsibility back: 'What can you do to bring me some facts to help me understand where you are?'

examples.name: Six Core Business Benefits
examples.content: Dan's value proposition includes five primary benefits: 'Financial clarity, sounding board for the owner, the person who ensures the execution of the owner's wishes, improved profitability, improved accountability.' He adds a sixth: 'a happier team' when prompted, noting 'That a big one.'

examples.name: Unconscious Accounting Attraction
examples.content: When asked what attracted him to accounting, Dan responds 'God I ask myself that every day... I don't even know that it was conscious.' He traces it to high school bookkeeping: 'Probably the symmetry of dividends equalling credits and the logic of it. So, I got it' plus knowing 'it was a very solid field to go into.'

examples.name: Trusted Advisor Continuity
examples.content: Dan sees his current work as continuous with his early career: 'in some ways, I think it's no different than coming right out of college into a public accounting firm. I was still working with business owners in a much more specialized capacity, but I was still advising, and I was acting as a trusted advisor.'

examples.name: Early Business Exposure Foundation
examples.content: Dan identifies formative influences as 'my dad being self-employed' and 'seeing a couple of brothers who own businesses' as factors that shaped his approach to work and business.

examples.name: Corporate Boredom and Disruption Pattern
examples.content: Dan describes getting 'bored easily to the point where if I had the opportunity to break something, I would. That way, I had something else to do or to push just to go do something new.' He views 'company life as pretty much a 12-month cycle' where 'not that much new happens year to year.'

examples.name: Realization About External Stimulation Need
examples.content: When leaving Macy's for public accounting, a friend said 'I get why you left, but you are where you need to be.' This led to the realization 'I need that phone to ring because it's nothing to do' - recognizing the need for external stimulation and variety.

examples.name: Shiny Object Owner Roadblock Example
examples.content: Dan worked with an owner who 'loves to chase shiny red objects' and 'remains the roadblock two months later' despite hiring help. When she presented a laundry list of 'fires that have to be put out,' he listened for 'what the true priorities are, not necessarily based on revenue impact but based on what it's going to take to get her working on the right things to get her out of the mud.'

examples.name: Time Freedom Priority Test
examples.content: Dan used a specific test: 'what if this week we did nothing more than number two and number three? What impact would that have?' When she said it 'would free up a lot of time long-term,' he reframed: 'is that really our priority to get you to do what you're best at versus all the stuff that you're doing right now? She got it.'

examples.name: Brian's Business-First Mental Model Development
examples.content: Dan wants warehouse manager Brian to 'recognize' that 'acting in the best interest of the business is the best way to act.' Brian 'tends to put the customer first, regardless of the financial implications,' so Dan teaches balance: 'It's not always about the financial decision. It's not always about the customer. There's a balance that needs to be struck.' Dan also notes Brian 'doesn't ask more of himself or the team' but finds this harder to address.

examples.name: Sawmill Owner Jo Relationship Learning
examples.content: At the sawmill, owner Jo 'wasn't very sophisticated or understanding of business or finance' and 'would just want what she wanted.' Dan's insistence on doing what was 'right' would 'just set me up to fail' and 'end up pissing her off because I wasn't doing it her way, even though it was wrong.' This taught him flexibility over rigidity.

examples.name: The Limited Internal Fury Pattern
examples.content: At The Limited, when Dan thought something was wrong, he 'would be furious internally, and it would cause me to lose interest for a period of time. I would almost become detached because I didn't want to have anything to do with it.' This pattern of rigidity became professionally limiting.

examples.name: External vs Internal Project Performance Difference
examples.content: When asked about achieving flow state on his own projects versus external consulting work, Dan reveals that he needs to 'know someone is relying on me' to reach peak 'intensity of not only quality but just thought process.' While he can work for himself, optimal performance requires knowing 'the output will be used by someone else.'

examples.name: Root Cause vs. Tool-Throwing Approach
examples.content: Dan's decision architecture centers on 'Root cause' analysis, requiring patience: 'You'll never get to the root cause in the first conversation... even two or three conversations in, you still haven't drilled down into the core issue.' He contrasts this with others who 'just throw ideas and tools out to try to solve those surface-level issues and then declare victory. But it hasn't necessarily built a stronger company.'

examples.name: Current Role Frame
examples.content: When asked about his current role perspective, Dan identifies as 'that fractional advisor. You know, COO CFO' - positioning himself as operational and financial leadership rather than pure consulting.

examples.name: Job Description Philosophy Evolution
examples.content: Dan's approach to hiring evolved from trying to find 'right people on the bus in the right seats' to believing 'you just need good people and give them direction.' When reviewing job descriptions 15-20 years ago, he would 'throw out the tasks and I would write about the importance or the value because that's what will attract people.'

examples.name: Critical Thinking Discovery and Application
examples.content: Dan discovered the importance of critical thinking '10 or 15 years ago' and now believes 'critical thinking is everything. Business acumen is really important. If you get those right, you can put that person in almost any role and they'll do well.' He evaluates 'critical thinking in our first conversation' rather than using skills tests.

examples.name: Accounting Foundation as Daily Tool
examples.content: Dan identifies his 'master's in accounting, CPA, and working at a large public accounting CPA firm' as the foundation he returns to 'almost every day, whether I want to or not.' This knowledge is valuable 'because it's knowledge that most small business owners don't have.'

examples.name: Arthur Anderson Elevated Status
examples.content: Working at Arthur Anderson, 'one of the largest firms in the world,' provided elevated status in Cincinnati where 'if you worked there, you had an elevated status,' establishing early credibility that influences ongoing professional positioning.

examples.name: Manufacturing Company Planning Session Flow
examples.content: Dan achieves flow state leading planning sessions for companies, often their first time coming together beyond holiday parties to discuss business future. He starts with strengths/weaknesses, reads the room for tension, and proactively addresses sales/operations stereotypes by acknowledging how each group is typically perceived, creating a foundation of 'we are literally all in this together.'

examples.name: Comprehensive Expertise Inventory
examples.content: Dan's mini-expertise areas include: 'Financial analysis, accounting, bookkeeping, sales tax planning, relationship building, pricing, margin analysis, inventory analysis, vendor negotiation... delegation model... clarifying roles and responsibilities. Being a sounding board and being willing to tell the owner what they want to hear, whether they want to hear it or not.'

examples.name: Switzerland Neutrality Metaphor
examples.content: Dan describes his role as 'Switzerland' to employees: 'I freely admit I am being paid by the owner, but I work for the company, and I'm going to work in the best interest of the company, not the owner, understanding that if I do something that is not in the best interest of the owner, I'll get fired.'

examples.name: Early Passion for Influence
examples.content: Dan traces his motivation back to high school: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for being class president.' Early career passion was 'money and the prestige' with 'the goal was partner.'

examples.name: Partner Role Model Disillusionment
examples.content: After having children, Dan realized 'very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' This led him to leave the partnership track.

examples.name: Critical Thinking vs. Moonshot Goals Tension
examples.content: Dan explores the tension between critical thinking and creative problem-solving, noting that 'too much critical thinking could get in the way because your logic brain is shutting down too much of the "what if".' He suggests 'moonshot goals probably don't sit well with a critical thinker because I can't envision it, but I certainly can't figure out how to get there.'

examples.name: Uncovering vs. Creating Relationships
examples.content: When asked about the creative aspect of connecting dots, Dan initially says it's 'more to do with uncovering what's already there. It's your ability to draw conclusions, not out of thin air, but by seeing relationships that others don't see.' However, he acknowledges 'I think you can create a relationship. Sure.'

examples.name: Leadership Team Member Retirement Facilitation
examples.content: At the manufacturing company, a leadership team member 'had to go for a million reasons' but no one would make the decision. Dan 'painted the picture that there is a future, and she's not part of it' and allowed her to process. She ultimately chose announced retirement with continued health insurance for upcoming surgery. 'It was all her decision' publicly, though 'I was the only one who could make that happen.'

examples.name: Operations vs HR Discipline Mediation
examples.content: When operations and HR conflicted over disciplining a valuable but problematic sawmill worker in rural Indiana, Dan acted 'almost like a negotiator going back and forth' between them. Though 'both of them knew I could just make a decision to be done with it,' he facilitated a compromise solution (suspension while keeping employment) that served 'the best decision for the business.'

examples.name: Unexpected Call Examples
examples.content: Dan describes receiving unexpected calls from business owners about deeply personal decisions: 'getting a divorce. About their business partner' and decisions about 'finally fire their first person.' These calls represent moments when people rely on him for guidance to feel 'better and a little bit more confident about whatever that next step is.'

examples.name: What Would Be Most Missed
examples.content: When asked what he would miss most if he retired, Dan immediately responds 'The unexpected phone call' - indicating that spontaneous moments of being needed for major life and business decisions represent the core value and satisfaction of his work.

examples.name: The Drive for Client Reliance
examples.content: When pressed about what emotionally drives his excitement in helping businesses, Dan reveals 'what I really want... But I want them to rely on me.' This reliance validates that 'my previous work has helped them' and indicates 'they want more' - not necessarily to pay more, but because they genuinely value the ongoing help.

examples.name: Reading People - Logic vs Emotion Assessment
examples.content: When reading people as individuals beyond their roles, Dan focuses on 'listening for resistance to whatever I'm saying' and determining 'whether that resistance is passing any logical test or whether it's pure emotion.' The same applies to agreement - he needs to know people are 'landing on the logic side' because he will 'probably dismiss what you have to say from the emotional side.'

examples.name: Critical Thinking Teachability Limits
examples.content: Dan acknowledges 'You can teach critical thinking. I've done it. I taught a short course on critical thinking' to explain what it is and why it's important. However, 'if you're lousy, you can't become excellent. You can improve' - there are natural ceilings to development.

examples.name: Critical Thinking as Media Immunity
examples.content: Dan sees critical thinking as broader than problem-solving, enabling you to 'go through an election season and not get crazy from the ads. Because the left is as full of shit as the right. It's just an ad... I don't act on it because they haven't given me enough information to draw the conclusion they want me to draw.'

examples.name: Google Ads Verification and Growth Moderation
examples.content: Dan found Google Ads represented 'the single biggest expense in overhead' with claimed 10x ROI. He said 'Until I prove it, I'm not going to say that you're wrong... I just have to know for myself that it's true.' The actual ROI was 7.6x. When the owner wanted to 'increase it 20% every month,' Dan advised 'let's just slow down a little bit. Let's just be a little bit more deliberate.'

examples.name: Urgent vs. Important Priority Problem
examples.content: With a business owner 45 days behind in billing with no cash, Dan identified the core issue: 'We have a priority problem here... We're not working on what's important. We're working on what's urgent. All day long.' He forces delegation by 'badger her with texts and requests' until she agrees to hand over operational tasks.

examples.name: Company Enablement Framing
examples.content: When meeting the warehouse manager, Dan framed his role: 'Dan really thinks he's got the formula figured out and he really wants to grow. I said my job is to make sure the rest of the company can keep up with his plans.' This positions him as supporting the owner's vision rather than imposing external control.

examples.name: Crisis Intuition Branching
examples.content: In crisis situations without a plan, Dan describes intuition as having two potential paths: 'It could be blur out something and solve the problem. Or your intuition could be, I need to get more information, and I need these people to... I need someone else to help me make this decision.' The intuition guides process selection rather than direct answers.

examples.name: Attorney Network Learning Experience
examples.content: At the Limited, Dan gained 'exposure of working with various attorneys in thirty different states' and learning from them during dinners and social interactions. He notes 'you just learn a lot, not about law and taxes, but in everything' and that 'most attorneys are huge history buffs' who know their local history extensively.

examples.name: Big Company Perspective Advantage
examples.content: Dan's career progression from large CPA firm specialist to Limited corporate role to local CPA firm allows him to 'bring them a big company and big CPA firm perspective that they otherwise don't get' when working with small businesses.

examples.name: President with Negative Filter Example
examples.content: Dan worked with a company president whose 'filter is so pronounced that there's a filter embedded with this trepidation over anything new.' This caused them to 'hear things completely differently' when sitting together - the president's filter 'caused him to hear things that are always negatively and things that could always go wrong.' Result: 'in two years, he was president, he never made a good decision. He couldn't because he couldn't hear it.'

examples.name: Critical Thinking Definition and Reception Importance
examples.content: Dan defines critical thinking as 'the ability to accept information and connect the dots for decision-making' but emphasizes that 'how you receive information is just as important as how you process it.' Optimal reception is '80% objective and 20% subjective' with 'very strong emotional intelligence' to avoid immediate reactions.

examples.name: Current Passion Definition
examples.content: When asked about passion for his current work, Dan explains: 'I just help someone has a problem... When we're finished talking about it or I go off and do something and come back to them, they feel better for it. It's not about giving an answer.' The satisfaction comes from providing relief rather than solutions.

examples.name: Teaching as Career Analog
examples.content: When asked about applying his skills to another career, Dan identifies teaching: 'you're not helping with a current problem but you're taking all of your experience and helping them to understand the problem and maybe avoid them down the road.' This represents the same helping function with a prevention focus.

examples.name: Help Philosophy Evolution
examples.content: Dan describes a fundamental shift in his understanding: 'Earlier... I thought help meant giving answers. Help really means leading people to a better solution.' This represents evolution from directive to facilitative helping approach.

examples.name: Customer Service Employee Termination Support
examples.content: Dan worked with a small company owner who struggled to fire an evasive customer service employee who avoided phone calls and worked remotely while 'riding his bike.' Despite evidence from phone logs and tracking, the owner 'knew he had to do it, he wanted to do it, but he didn't know how.' Dan spent '90 minutes' on vacation talking through the process until the owner had both clarity and confidence to act.

examples.name: Clarity Before Confidence Process
examples.content: Dan's unique approach is giving owners 'confidence and clarity... It's strike that clarity then confidence. They have to have the clarity first of why they're doing it, because if there's this much hesitation, it gets blown up.' The sequence ensures that understanding the rationale precedes building courage to act.

examples.name: Profit Levers Hierarchy
examples.content: Dan identifies key profit levers starting with 'revenue growth, which involves whether that is marketing, pricing, really understanding who your customer is' with the caveat that 'not every sale is a good sale.' He emphasizes that 'most businesses don't pay enough attention to gross margin' and focus too much on cutting overhead when 'the real drivers are above the line more so than below the line.'

examples.name: Paper Clips vs. Real Drivers
examples.content: Dan describes the common mistake where businesses 'spend all their time trying to not by paper clips this month or cut back on supplies so that they could make their number' when they should focus on 'revenue and the cost of sale.' While 'any business can find 10% or 20% savings in overhead easily... that's not driving your business anywhere.'

examples.name: Building Up the Number Twos and Threes
examples.content: Dan identifies working with overlooked number twos and threes as something he would miss. He describes going 'right away' to these overlooked people, building them up because 'even though often the owner says they rely on them and they do, but not to the extent that they should.' These interactions involve 'give and take' where he steps into 'the role of the owner' to help them develop perspective.

examples.name: Person Decisions as Core Business Pain
examples.content: When asked about important business decisions, Dan immediately identifies: 'Most often, the decision is what do I do about this person? That's the pain point... that becomes a core issue from the person I'm working with.' This represents the fundamental challenge in most business consulting situations.

examples.name: Offsite for Owner Recognition, Not Planning
examples.content: Dan planned to suggest a 'half-day offsite with all of her key people' for the shiny-object-chasing owner, 'not to create some great plan. I do that so that the owner either remembers or recognizes that the people on their team have some really good ideas and you need to listen to them instead of just running around in a frenzy.'

examples.name: Team Health Over Tactical Solutions
examples.content: Dan's decision architecture: 'The pricing stuff and profit, those are tactics... the only way the company becomes healthier, and it doesn't matter what its problem is, it's only going to help become healthier if those key people in the owner become much more of a team because they're not right now.'

examples.name: Drucker's Department Store Prediction
examples.content: Dan admires Drucker's predictive ability, citing how he wrote 'an article about department stores in the seventies, telling us why they're not going to survive.' Drucker understood that department stores originally offered 'a different experience for each class' but failed to adapt when 'everything became about time' due to more women entering the workforce. While department stores 'kept focusing on fashion,' Target and Costco succeeded because 'they addressed the real issue of time.'

examples.name: Drucker's Human Element Focus
examples.content: Dan values Drucker not primarily for knowledge worker concepts but because Drucker 'never let go of the human element of anything that he did, and he still doesn't seem to get very much credit for that.' From Drucker, Dan learned to focus on 'what's the real' - understanding underlying human needs rather than surface business assumptions.

examples.name: High School Class President Leadership Lessons
examples.content: Dan was class president for 'three or four years' in high school, missing only junior year because he 'didn't run' due to other commitments. This experience taught him early 'that you can't lead all people? Some people don't want to be led.'

examples.name: College Soccer Coach Collaboration Challenge
examples.content: As women's soccer coach in college, Dan had to 'orchestrate this mess for the greater good' focused on 'the team's success' rather than personal gain. As 'a freshman coach to 22 women, most of whom were older than me,' he learned that successful coaching requires being 'a collaborator' while also knowing when to 'put your foot down.'

examples.name: Universal Strength Claims Pattern
examples.content: Dan observes that in SWOT analysis, 'Everyone says they're responsive. Everyone says they're adaptable. Everyone says that they value teamwork and or collaborators, or they engage in consultative selling.' He's particularly skeptical of responsiveness claims: 'I think they're full of shit about responsiveness.'

examples.name: Consensus Priority Over Truth
examples.content: When asked how important it is to verify claimed strengths, Dan emphasizes: 'I want team consensus... Even if this has happened, even if I don't believe it, not my plan.' Team agreement takes precedence over factual accuracy in the SWOT process.

examples.name: Collaboration Components Breakdown
examples.content: Dan identifies collaboration as having three components: ideas, information, and personalized evaluation based on understanding each person's thinking style. This includes accommodating those who 'go off very quickly' and allowing others who 'literally need to go away and then come back' to process.

examples.name: Tuesday Crisis Response Pattern
examples.content: When a crisis happens on a Tuesday requiring immediate response, Dan's innate response is to first communicate that 'we're not looking at something that is the end of the world' while acknowledging its importance, then shift into collaborative mode to rapidly gather information rather than working alone.

examples.name: SWOT as Weakness Discovery Tool
examples.content: Dan's SWOT process is 'all about weaknesses' - using strengths and opportunities as setup to focus on obstacles. The key question: 'Are the weaknesses so pronounced that unless you get those corrected, the business cannot legitimately pursue the opportunities?' Most priorities address weaknesses because teams realize 'we can't get out of our own way.'

examples.name: Sandbox Ownership and Collective Responsibility
examples.content: Dan creates 'sandbox' ownership where 'no one else is allowed in your sandbox' including the owner, but also establishes that 'everyone who attended the meeting is now responsible for all of these... If someone asks you to help, you have to help. It's not optional.' This combines individual authority with collective support.

examples.name: Binary Meeting Structure
examples.content: Dan's recurring meetings use EOS-flavored structure with fixed format: good news, metrics review, individual tasks, then open discussion. For all updates, 'the entire focus is it's on track or it's off track. That's all we need to know' to maintain pace and focus.

examples.name: Cincinnati Return Decision
examples.content: Dan left The Limited after nine years, feeling 'breathless' at the 'big, dumb company.' He was 'clearly putting the family ahead of my career' by moving back to Cincinnati where 'my whole family was here.' He believed 'in the long run, the kids would thrive back here or do better' and it 'turned out to be just absolutely the right decision.'

examples.name: Finality of Root-Setting
examples.content: The move back to Cincinnati 'felt final, meaning I never put down roots in Columbus.' This represents a commitment to place and community over career mobility, which Dan describes as 'a very local feeling' but 'kind of important.'

examples.name: Lincoln Leadership Fascination
examples.content: Dan maintains deep admiration for Lincoln, particularly 'the skill required to manage that cabinet and the Civil War and everything is just phenomenal.' He references 'Team of Rivals' and finds Lincoln's complex leadership under extreme pressure continuously fascinating, though he admits 'I just can't figure it out.'

examples.name: Evolution Away from Management Tools
examples.content: Dan describes moving away from management fads: 'I don't believe in any management tool or fed. Whereas maybe ten years ago I would have like this like we got to do the balanced scorecard.' He now believes 'the best plan is the plan that starts with a recognition of the owner's strengths and weaknesses' because if solutions 'always feels like someone else's, they do it for a year and then they quit.'

examples.name: Long-Term Uncertainty Process
examples.content: For problems with no clear path to certainty and months before results, Dan doesn't approach it differently: 'I'm not looking for the quick fix anyway. If most of the issues are people-related, none of that gets fixed quickly anyway. It's months... The process is much more about chipping away than just bringing a solution.'

examples.name: Employee Trust and Balanced Perspective Process
examples.content: Dan builds understanding through 'establishing trust with the employees... dealing with them one on one without the owner present, and in doing so, acknowledging some of the inconsistencies.' When employees complain, he 'jump back and forth between acknowledging some of the inconsistencies and defending the owner... Reminding them that the owner is the one who has risk.'

examples.name: Elementary School PTA President Revelation
examples.content: Ten to fifteen years ago as elementary school PTA president, Dan created 'an incredibly loyal group of people' despite the role meaning 'all the parents invent reasons to hate you.' A parent described him as 'very approachable,' which was a revelation: 'I had never thought about that before... that's always stuck with me.'

examples.name: Core Identity - Insight and Dot-Connection
examples.content: When asked about intrinsic identity traits, Dan identifies being 'insightful' as fundamental: 'I've always been insightful, and people just rely on that. They just rely on me to connect the dots for them.'

examples.name: Evolution from Profit as Result to Profit as Managed Goal
examples.content: Dan's approach has evolved to have 'greater focus on profit than ever before because earlier, my focus was more about profit as a result, not something to be managed.' He now realizes 'profit and cash are essentially the same thing' and that profit understanding is what enables 'their dreams, their employees' dreams, and just a better life.'

examples.name: Multi-Area Improvement Philosophy
examples.content: Dan's thinking evolved from fixating 'on just revenue, expenses, taxes, or something like that' to understanding 'it's much more complex to get there. You're not going to hit a home run on any one of those areas and declare victory. You're always improving each one of those areas' to create better profit opportunities.

examples.name: Natural Evolution as Unique Approach
examples.content: When asked about his unique process, Dan describes it as 'natural. It evolved... a series of small steps that added up to create a big impact... It's not an event.' This incremental approach differs from other consultants because 'they don't know how businesses really work' and 'they want to get paid for their big idea. And everyone who's inside an organization knows big ideas don't get implemented, they get killed.'
